senses.definition: a Central and South American bat (= an animal like a mouse with wings) that bites other animals and drinks their blood
the poisonous liquid that some snakes, spiders, etc. produce when they bite or sting you

examples.x: The snake injects the venom immediately after biting its prey.
Centipedes kill their prey by injecting venom into them with a large pair of fangs.
Snake venoms work in several ways.

senses.definition: a strong, bitter feeling; feelings of hate and a desire to hurt somebody

examples.x: His voice was full of venom.
a look of pure venom

senses.definition: wild animals or birds that destroy plants or food, or attack farm animals and birds

examples.x: On farms the fox is considered vermin and treated as such.

senses.definition: insects that live on the bodies of animals and sometimes humans

examples.x: The room was crawling with vermin.

senses.definition: people who are very unpleasant or dangerous to society
a small poisonous snake
a person who harms other people
a female fox (= a wild animal of the dog family)
an offensive word for a woman who is thought to be frightening, especially one who is considered sexually attractive
a small animal like a mouse or rat that lives in fields or near rivers
to move or go somewhere by putting one foot in front of the other on the ground, but without running creep

examples.x: The baby is just learning to walk.
He may not be able to walk again.
‘How did you get here?’ ‘I walked.’
He walked slowly away from her.
The door opened and Jo walked in.
She missed the bus and had to walk home.
He turned and walked away.
He started to walk away from me, but quickly returned.
People walking past were staring at him.
You don't mind walking back, do you?
It looks like a nice place to walk around.
He walks over to the window and looks out.
I just happened to be walking by.
We walked along in silence for a while.
I ignored him and walked on.
I always walk to school.
Taking a deep breath, she walked into the room.
He immediately got up and walked out of the room.
I walked in the door and looked around.
He walked out the door, got in his car, and drove off.
He greeted her as she walked through the door.
I was walking down the street when I suddenly felt ill.
The school is within easy walking distance of the train station.
They walked the dark streets of Los Angeles.
Children here walk several miles to school.
She walked the short distance to her flat.

senses.definition: to spend time walking for pleasure

examples.x: I like an active holiday, so I walk.
She's started to go walking.
We're going walking in the mountains this summer.
I walked across Scotland with a friend.
They love walking the moors.

senses.definition: to go somewhere with somebody on foot, especially in order to make sure they get there safely

examples.x: He always walked her home.
I walked him to the corner of the street.

senses.definition: to take an animal for a walk; to make an animal walk somewhere take

examples.x: They walk their dogs every day.
She walked the horse around the ring.

senses.definition: to disappear; to be taken away

examples.x: Lock up any valuables. Things tend to walk here (= be stolen).

senses.definition: to appear
when a batter walks, they leave the field without waiting for the umpire to say that they are out

examples.x: He knew he was out, so he walked.

senses.definition: to reach first base without having to do anything because the pitcher failed to throw the ball correctly four times and you didn't try to hit it; to enable a batter to walk

examples.x: He walked 60 times in 57 games.
Despite walking one batter, Jackson showed solid control of the pitch.

senses.definition: an Australian animal like a small kangaroo, that moves by jumping on its strong back legs and keeps its young in a pouch (= a pocket of skin) on the front of the mother’s body
an animal like a large seal (= a sea animal with thick fur, that eats fish and lives around coasts), that has two long outer teeth called tusks and lives in Arctic regions Walrus
having a warm blood temperature that does not change if the temperature around them changes Warm-blooded
an African wild pig with two large outer teeth called tusks and growths like warts on its face
a large African antelope that lives near rivers and lakes

examples.x: Lake Nakuru is home to rhinos, hippos, waterbucks and buffalo.

senses.definition: a large Asian animal of the cow family, used for pulling vehicles and farm equipment in tropical countries
a poisonous snake that lives near water in the US
an animal like a rat that swims and lives in a hole next to a river or lake
an animal like a rat that swims and lives in a hole next to a river or lake
a small wild animal with red-brown fur, a long thin body, and short legs. Weasels eat smaller animals. Weasel
a very large animal that lives in the sea and looks like a very large fish. There are several types of whale, some of which are hunted. wail

examples.x: whale meat
We saw a whale blowing a jet of spray high in the air.
management and conservation of whale stocks

senses.definition: to make low, weak crying noises; to speak in this way

examples.x: The dog whimpered softly.
The child was lost and began to whimper.
‘Don't leave me alone,’ he whimpered.

senses.definition: a low, weak sound that a person or an animal makes when they are hurt, frightened or sad

examples.x: The puppy gave a little whimper of fear.
She let out a whimper of pain.
The animal gave a pathetic little whimper.
The whole affair ended less with a bang than with a whimper (= in a way that was not impressive).

senses.definition: a small, thin dog, similar to a greyhound, that can run very fast and is often used for racing
any of the long, stiff hairs that grow near the mouth of a cat, mouse, etc.
the hair growing on a man’s face, especially on the sides of his face
living or growing in natural conditions; not kept in a house or on a farm

examples.x: wild animals/birds/flowers
wild salmon
wild mushrooms/rice
The plants grow wild along the banks of rivers.
Their aim is to document wild populations of fast-disappearing species.
a wild boar

senses.definition: in its natural state; not changed by people

examples.x: the destruction of forests and other wild lands
wild moorland
The island is a wild and lonely place.
This is truly wild and unspoilt countryside.

senses.definition: having no discipline or control

examples.x: The boy is wild and completely out of control.
He had a wild look in his eyes.
a woman with wild hair
wild mood swings

senses.definition: full of very strong feeling

examples.x: The crowd went wild.
It makes me wild (= very angry) to see such waste.
Everything about her drove him wild (= made him like her very much).
wild laughter/celebrations
The couple were dancing with wild abandon.

senses.definition: not carefully planned; not sensible or accurate

examples.x: He made a wild guess at the answer.
wild accusations

senses.definition: very good, pleasant or exciting

examples.x: We had a wild time in New York.

senses.definition: very enthusiastic about somebody/something

examples.x: She's totally wild about him.
She was absolutely wild about him.
I'm not wild about the idea.

senses.definition: affected by storms and strong winds

examples.x: a wild night
The sea was wild.

senses.definition: a wild pig
a type of small wild cat that lives in mountains and forests
animals, birds, insects, etc. that are wild and live in a natural environment

examples.x: policies designed to protect wildlife
Development of the area would endanger wildlife.
a wildlife habitat
a wildlife refuge/sanctuary

senses.definition: the highest part of a horse’s back, between its shoulders
a large wild animal of the dog family, that lives and hunts in groups

examples.x: She compared the media to a pack of ravening/ravenous wolves.

senses.definition: a very large, tall dog with long hair and long legs, originally used for hunting wolves

examples.x: an Irish wolfhound

senses.definition: a wild animal that looks similar to a small bear, with short legs, long brown hair and a long tail. Wolverines live in cold, northern areas of Europe and North America.
an Australian animal like a small bear, that carries its young in a pouch (= a pocket of skin) on the front of the mother’s body
a small North American animal of the squirrel family wood
a word used to describe the loud noise that a dog makes

examples.x: ‘Woof! Woof!’ he barked.

senses.definition: to make the loud noise that a dog makes
the loud noise that a dog makes

examples.x: the distant woof of a dog

senses.definition: the threads that are twisted under and over the threads that are held on a loom (= a frame or machine for making cloth)
the soft hair that covers the body of sheep and some other animals

examples.x: Sheep were kept for their wool and meat.

senses.definition: long, thick thread made from animal’s wool, used for knitting (= making clothing with wool using two long needles or a machine)

examples.x: a ball of wool
I bought knitting wool for a cardigan.
She’s knitting a jumper in pure wool.
She spun wool by hand to weave into clothing.

senses.definition: cloth made from animal’s wool, used for making clothes, etc.

examples.x: This scarf is 100% wool.
pure new wool
a wool blanket/sweater

senses.definition: an animal of the cow family, with long horns and long hair, that lives in Central Asia
a very small dog with long brown and grey hair
an African wild animal like a horse with black and white stripes (= lines) on its body Zebra
an animal of the cow family with long horns and a hump (= high part) on its back, kept on farms especially in hot climates

examples.x: Kenya's beef comes from the zebu cattle.
